message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only t(9;22) is associated with an unfavorable prognosis in ALL. This chromosomal translocation creates the Philadelphia chromosome, which is most commonly found in chronic myelogenous leukemia but can also be seen in some cases of ALL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is asking for the chromosomal abnormality associated with an unfavorable prognosis in a patient with ALL of precursor-B subtype. Among the options, only t(9;22), also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, is associated with a poor prognosis. Trisomy 4 and 10 are not commonly associated with ALL, while t(12;21) is associated with a more favorable prognosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. t(9;22), also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, is associated with an unfavorable prognosis in ALL. Trisomies 4 and 10 are not usually associated with ALL, and t(12;21) is actually associated with a favorable prognosis.

Among the options, only t(9;22), also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, is associated with an unfavorable prognosis in ALL, as it leads to the production of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein. Trisomy 4 and trisomy 10 are not commonly associated with ALL, and t(12;21) is associated with a more favorable prognosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The options presented are commonly found chromosomal abnormalities in ALL. Among them, t(9;22) is associated with a poor prognosis and higher relapse rates. Trisomy 4 and 10 are generally considered low-risk abnormalities and t(12;21) is associated with a favorable prognosis. Therefore, the correct answer is (C).

The t(9;22) translocation, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, is associated with an unfavorable prognosis in ALL. Trisomy 4 and trisomy 10 are not common abnormalities in ALL, while t(12;21) is associated with a favorable prognosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is asking about chromosomal abnormalities associated with unfavorable prognosis in the patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia of precursor-B subtype. Among the options, only t(9;22) is associated with an unfavorable prognosis, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome. Trisomy 4 and trisomy 10 are not specifically associated with unfavorable prognoses, and t(12;21) is associated with a favorable prognosis in children.
